metadata.title: Title: Household transmissions of SARS-CoV-2 in the time of unprecedented travel 1 lockdown in China 2 3

body_text.text: In total 34 primary cases were identified as super spreaders, and 5 household super-spreading 61 events were observed. The mean serial interval is estimated to be 4.95 days (standard deviation: 5.24 62 days) and 5.19 days (standard deviation: 5.28 days) for households and non-household transmissions, 63 respectively. The risk of being infected outside of households is higher for age groups between 18 and 64 64 years, whereas the hazard of being infected within households is higher for age groups of young 65 (<18) and elderly (>65) people. (Table S9) . We compiled a line-list database from these reports with 112 extracted demographic characteristics, social relationships, travel history, timelines of potential 113 exposure, symptom onset, confirmation and hospitalization. We estimated the daily number of passengers leaving each province by 116 using the migration scale index for moving out of that province each day. More details on our real-time 117 mobility and line-list case data are provided in Supplemental Material and will be available at our 118 GitHub.

We identified 1,407 infection events with known social relationships. For each infection event, we term 121 the infector the primary case and the infectee the secondary case. We also consider connected chains of 122 confirmed cases; we term the original case the index and the entire chain of cases, including the index,

The age-stratified hazard of infection for household relative to non-household contacts is estimated by 133 the ratio between the probability that a secondary case of age group b was infected by a primary case of 134 age group a within the same household and the probability that a secondary case of age group b was 135 infected by a primary case of age group a outside of households. Gender-specific hazard of infection is 136 measured similarly (Supplemental Material).

We reconstructed 643 transmission clusters from 1,407 infection events (Figure 2a) . The sizes of 587 139 transmission clusters are smaller than 5, whereas the size of the largest cluster exceeds 20. We

The hazard of being infected within households is higher for age groups of young (<18) and elderly 149 (>65) people, whereas the hazard of being infected outside of households is higher for age groups 150 between 18 and 64 years (Table 1a ). Primary cases of elderly (>65) people are more prone to cause 151 household infections. Hazard of infection between different genders is higher for households than non-152 household transmission (Table 1b) . Table S2 ).
Household study helps identify risk factors for certain demographic groups 12 . The age-stratified and
We estimate that the mean serial interval is ~5 days for both household and non-household infections,

The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.02.20029868 doi: medRxiv preprint which is considerably shorter than the mean serial interval estimated for SARS (e.g., 8.4 days 15 ) and 175 MERS (e.g. 7.6 days 16 ). These evidences impose a significant barrier to case identification and 176 management. FIGREF0.text: Conclusions and RelevanceThe identification of super-spreading events, short serial intervals, and a67 higher risk of being infected outside of households for male people of age between 18 and 64 indicate a 68 significant barrier to the case identification and management, which calls for intensive non-69 pharmaceutical interventions (e.g. cancellation of public gathering, limited access of public services) health emergency of international significance on 30 January 2020 1 and classified the threat as 89 a global pandemic on 11 March 2020 2 . More than 118,326 confirmed cases and 4,292 deaths have 90 been reported as of 11 March 2020. The majority of cases in China (67,773) were from Hubei 91 Province 3 .

FIGREF1.text: 2020, China raised the national emergency response to the highest level, triggered an 93 unprecedented travel ban starting from the lockdown of Wuhan on 23 January, and 14 cities nearby 94 Wuhan on 24 January, and more than 30 provinces thereafter (Figure 1a). Although this countrywide 95 travel lockdown was aimed to interrupt case exportations from the epicenter, we have estimated 130 96 (95% CrI: 190, 369) high-risk cities that have introduced SARS-CoV-2 cases prior to Wuhan's 97 lockdown 4 . Recent studies 5,6 report similar estimates for the rapid geographic expansion of SARS-98 CoV-2. These coincide with the frequent reporting of infection events in China outside of Hubei99Province during the three weeks following Wuhan's lockdown(Figure 1c).

FIGREF2.text: Since the last week of January 2020, more than 260 Chinese cities have implemented intensive non-101 pharmaceutical controls (Figure 1b), which brought the epidemic under control 7,8,9 . However, as of 19 102 February 2020, this epidemic still has caused >10,000 cases in China outside of Hubei Province. To 103 enhance public health preparedness and public awareness, Chinese health authorities have publicly 104 reported detailed records of confirmed cases since 20 January 2020. This provides a unique resource 105 and an opportunity for understanding the transmission patterns, routes, and risk factors of the COVID-106 19 epidemic.

FIGREF3.text: China, 27 provincial and 264 urban health commissions have publicly posted 9,120 confirmed case 110 reports online since 20 January 2020, which comprises 72.7% of all cases confirmed in China outside

FIGREF6.text: We stratify infection events by household versus non-household transmissions, where household 125 includes any infection event among members within the same family (e.g., between parents and 126 children), and non-household include all others (e.g. colleagues, classmates). The numbers of 127 household (662) and non-household (745) infection events are almost even.

FIGREF7.text: each infection event with known symptom onset timelines, we compute the serial interval, i.e., the 129 number of days between the reported symptom onset date for the primary case and that for the 130 secondary case. We estimate the distribution of serial intervals by fitting a normal distribution to 679 131 infection events with known serial intervals (Supplemental Material).

FIGREF8.text: cases acting as super spreaders. Stratification by household shows that 356, 92,141 and 34 primary cases infected only 1 member, 2 members, and at least 3 familial members within 142 households, respectively; 276, 78, and 75 primary cases infected 1, 2, and at least 3 secondary cases 143 outside households, respectively (Figure 2b). Only 5 household super-spreading events were observed.

FIGREF9.text: 1,407 infection events formed 643 transmission clusters from 9,120 COVID-19 cases 155 confirmed in China outside of Hubei Province as of 19 February 2020. The entire database will be 156 available at our GitHub.

FIGREF10.text: 157Although super-spreading events have been reported by media reports and a recent study 11 which 158 focuses on special settings (e.g., restaurant, chalet) before February 2020, systematic analyses with a 159 sufficiently large sample size is lacking. Here, we identified 34 primary cases classified as super-160 spreader. Majority of the super-spreading events involve more non-household transmissions than 161 household transmissions. This indicates the importance of non-pharmaceutical interventions (e.g. 162 cancellation of public gatherings, limited access of public services) as the potential mitigation 163 strategies (see

FIGREF11.text: 165gender-specific hazard of infection suggests a higher risk of infection within households for age groups 166 of young (<18) and elderly (>65) and female people. The higher risk of being infected outside of 167 households for male people of age between 18 and 64 years indicates their role in driving household 168 secondary infections in the households included in our data, perhaps because these were travelers from 169 Wuhan of working age.

FIGREF12.text: We identified 55 infection events (~4%) with the secondary case reporting symptom onset prior to the 171 primary case, which is consistent with our preliminary analysis 4 and recent clinical reports 13,14 .

FIGREF13.text: Negative-valued serial intervals indicate the potential occurrence of pre-symptomatic transmissions.

FIGREF14.text: Our findings have several limitations. First, the size of each household and the primary cases without 178 secondary infections are unknown from original disclosures. This may give biased estimates if we 179 estimate the household reproduction number and secondary attack rate from raw data. Field surveys 180 will be helpful to adjust biases. Second, the information on nosocomial infections is unknown from 181 original disclosures, so that the observation of super-spreading events may be less common Hospital Outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus. FIGREF17.text: Changing patterns of population movements, non-pharmaceutical control measures, 275 and epidemic curve of infection events in China outside of Hubei Province. (a) Relative change in 276 the outbound travel volume (i.e., daily number of passengers) moving out of each province in China 277 from 1 January to 13 February 2020. The baseline daily outbound travel volume of a given province is 278 estimated by the mean daily number of passengers moving out of that province between 3 January 279 2020 and 9 January 2020 (i.e., the last week prior to the start of the Spring Festival travel season). The 280 relative change in outbound travel volume of province i on a given date T i is measured by the ratio 281 between the estimated number of passengers moving out of province i on date T i and the baseline daily 282 outbound travel volume of province i. Each row denotes a province, with Hubei Province highlighted 283 in red. Columns from left to right are ordered by calendar days. For the color bar, the dark red and blue 284 indicate a significant decrease and increase in the outbound travel volume, respectively. The Spring 285 Festival travel season officially started on 10 January 2020. The Lunar New Year holiday started on 25 286 January 2020 and was extended to 8 February 2020. The lockdown of Wuhan started on 23 January 287 2020. The end date of Spring Festival travel season is not clear because of the countrywide travel 288 lockdown. (b) The timing of epidemiological events and implementation of non-pharmaceutical control 289 measures in 263 cities in China. The size of circles is proportional to the number of cities. The vertical 290 grey dashed line indicates the timing of Wuhan's lockdown. (c) The date of symptom onset for 291 secondary cases caused by household (light pink) and non-household (light blue) primary infections.

FIGREF18.text: COVID-19 transmission clusters. (a) 643 transmission clusters, stratified by the size of 296 cluster n. Red, green and blue nodes denote primary cases, household secondary cases and non-297 household secondary cases, respectively. (b) Distribution of the number of secondary infections caused 298 by each of the 809 primary cases. (c) Distribution of serial intervals, which is fitted to 679 infection 299 events with known symptom onset timelines. For household transmissions, fitting with a normal 300 distribution suggests a mean serial interval of 4.95 days (standard deviation: 5.24 days); for non-301 household transmissions, fitting with a normal distribution suggests a mean serial interval of 5.19 days 302 (standard deviation: 5.28 days). Alternative distributions fitted for the serial interval can be found in 303

TABREF0.text: The mean serial interval is estimated to be 4.95 days (standard deviation: 5.24 days) within households, 145 and 5.19 days (standard deviation: 5.28 days) for non-household transmissions. Notably, 26 of 339 146 household-and 29 of 340 non-household infection events reported negative-valued serial intervals, 147 implying pre-symptomatic transmission.

TABREF2.text: Hazard of infection stratified by age or gender. (a) Age-stratified hazard of infection for the household relative to non-household transmission. (b) Gender-specific hazard of infection for the household relative to non-household transmission. Red or blue shades indicate an increased or 309 decreased hazard of infection within households relative to outside of households, respectively.
